model_solution:
Step 1: Multiply the first row of the matrix by the column vector.
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 & 0 \\ -7 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ -1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3(4)+1(-1)+0(-2)\\ -7(4)+4(-1)+2(-2)\\ 0(4)+5(-1)+(-1)(-2) \end{pmatrix}\]
Step 2: Evaluate the expressions in the resulting column vector.
\[\begin{pmatrix} 12-1+0\\ -28-4-4\\ 0-5+2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 11\\ -36\\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]
Step 3: Write the result as a column vector.
\[\begin{pmatrix} 11 \\ -36 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]
Step 4: The result is already a column vector, so no further action is required.
Step 5:
\[\begin{pmatrix} 11 \\ -36 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]
The final answer is: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 11 \\ -36 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}$

\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 & 0 \\ -7 & 4 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ -1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3(4)+1(-1)+0(-2)\\ -7(4)+4(-1)+2(-2)\\ 0(4)+5(-1)+(-1)(-2) \end{pmatrix}\]

Step 2: Evaluate the expressions in the resulting column vector.
\[\begin{pmatrix} 12-1+0\\ -28-4-4\\ 0-5+2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 11\\ -36\\ -3 \end{pmatrix}\]

Step 3: Write the result as a column vector.
